title: Active vs Passive Scanning
content: Passive scanning is looking without purpose—your eyes move but your brain isn't searching for anything specific. Active scanning is deliberately seeking critical information using structured patterns. In high-risk operations, passive scanning misses subtle changes that matter. Train yourself to scan with intent, not habit.

mcq.question: An operator glances at the control panel every few minutes but isn't looking for anything specific. They're relying on alarms to notify them of problems. What's the risk?

options.A: No risk—alarms will catch any problems
options.B: They may miss developing trends that haven't reached alarm thresholds
options.C: This is appropriate for stable operations
options.D: Passive scanning is actually more effective for routine monitoring

mcq.explanation: Alarms activate at thresholds, not at the start of trends. Passive scanning misses the early development of problems that could be caught and addressed before becoming critical.

openQuestions: Do you scan actively or passively during routine operations? How do you know?
What would an active scan pattern look like for your primary work area?
